COLOMBO PORT CITY ECONOMIC COMMISSION BILL:

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) I wish to inform Parliament that I have received the Determination of the Supreme Court in respect of the Bill entitled Colombo Port City Economic Commission, which was challenged in the Supreme Court in terms of Article 121(1) of the Constitution.
The Determination of the Supreme Court as to the constitutionality of the Bill entitled Colombo Port City Economic Commission is as follows:

(i) The provisions of Clauses 3(6), 30(3) second proviso, 55(2) and 58(1) of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.

(ii) The provisions of Clauses 3(5) proviso, 3(7), 6(1)(b), 30(3) first proviso, 71(1) and 74 (interpretation Regulatory Authority) of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution.
However, the said inconstancies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.

and 68(3)(a) are inconsistent with Article 76 read with Articles 3 and 4 of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution and approved by the people at a Referendum by virtue of the provisions of Article 83.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.
(iv) The provisions of Clause 52(3) read with Clauses

52(5) and 71(2)(p) of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 148 of the Constitution read with Articles 3, 4 and 76 of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution and approved by the people at a Referendum by virtue of the provisions of Article 83.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.

(v) The provisions of Clauses 30(1), 33(1), 40(2) and 71(2)(l) of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 14(1)(h) of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of Supreme Court.
(vi) The provisions of Clause 53(2)(b) read with

Clause 53(3)(b) of the Bill is inconsistent with Article 76 of the Constitution read with Articles 3 and 4 of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution and approved by the people at a Referendum by virtue of the provisions of Article 83.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.
(vii) The provisions of Clause 60(c) and Clause 60(f)
of the Bill is inconsistent with Article 148 of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution.
However, the said inconsistencies will cease if the Clauses are amended as mentioned in the Determination of the Supreme Court.
(viii) The provisions of Clause 37 of the Bill are
inconsistent with Articles 12(1) and 14(1)(g) of the Constitution and could be validly passed only with the special majority provided for in Article 84(2) of the Constitution.

However, the said inconsistency will cease if a new sub-clause is added to Clause 37 of the Bill restraining such authorized person making use of any exemptions or incentives granted under this Bill when conducting business outside the Area of Authority of the Colombo Port City to the detriment of similar businesses conducted outside such Area of Authority but within the territory of Sri Lanka.
The Supreme Court has determined that the rest of the Clauses of the Bill are not inconsistent with the Constitution.
I order that the Determination of the Supreme Court be printed in the Official Report of todays Proceedings.

: IMPORT OF COCONUT OIL FROM 2015-2019: DETAILS

(a) Will he inform this House separately, pertaining to each year during the period from 2015 to 2019, - (i) the quantity of coconut oil imported to Sri Lanka; (ii) the money that has been incurred on that; (iii) the countries from which the coconut oil was imported; and (iv) the companies which imported the coconut oil? (b) Will he also inform this House of the total expenditure on importing coconut oil into Sri Lanka during the period concerned? (c ) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Bandula Gunawardana) , .

(ii) if so, of the machineries expected to be purchased;

POST OFFICES IN ANURADHAPURA DISTRICT: DETAILS
asked the Minister of Mass Media:
(i) the number of post offices of the Postal Department located in the Anuradhapura District;
(ii) the number of officers employed in those post offices;
(iii) out of the aforesaid number post offices, the number of those that are operating in buildings obtained on rent basis; and
(iv) whether steps have been taken to construct permanent buildings for those post offices?

: FEMALE PUBLIC SERVANTS RECRUITED UNDER GRADUATE TRAINING PROGRAMME: MATERNITY LEAVE ENTITLEMENT
) ( - ) (The Hon. Buddhika Pathirana on behalf of the Hon. Hesha Withanage) , - (1):
asked the Minister of Public Services, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) in terms of Sub-section 18:2:1 of Chapter XXII of the Establishments Code, every female public servant is entitled to a full paid leave of 84 working days for every live childbirth;
(ii) in terms of Sub-section 18:3:1 of the aforesaid Chapter, such female public servants are entitled to half-pay leave of 84 days to take care of the child;
(iii) in terms of Sub-section 18:4:1 of the aforesaid Chapter, a further 84 days of unpaid leave can be granted to such public servants, if requested; and
(iv) Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays during the holiday period shall be excluded in the calculation of leave under (i) above?

(i) whether he admits that, as per the appointment letters given to the female officers who have been recruited under the graduate training programme implemented by the then Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, they are granted maternity leave of only six weeks;
(ii) whether steps will be taken to grant them maternity leave that they are entitled to as per the Establishments Code;
(iii) if so, the date from which they will be granted such leave?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Johnston Fernando) , , * .
) ( - ) (The Hon. Buddhika Pathirana on behalf of the Hon. Chaminda Wijesiri) , - (0):

(ii) the numbers of financial irregularities and financial abuses pointed out by the audit queries concerned;
(iii) what audit recommendations have been given in this regard;
(iv) what steps will be taken to implement those audit recommendations; and
(v) what measures will be taken against the political authorities and officers involved in the financial irregularities and financial abuses?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Johnston Fernando) , , * .

() .. ( ) ( () .. - ) (The Hon. (Prof.) G.L. Peiris - Minister of Education) , , - Colombo Port City Economic Commission Bill - . . , . . . . , , . . . , . .

Hon. Presiding Member, there is some misinformation which is circulating throughout the country regarding the effect of the Supreme Court Determination that was announced to this august Assembly by the Hon. Speaker this morning. It is being said that the Supreme Court, in its Determination, has declared that a two-thirds majority and a Referendum is required in order to pass this Bill. That is totally, entirely incorrect, Mr. Presiding Member.

The Government, through the Department of the Attorney-General, submitted to the Supreme Court a series of Amendments. The Court has accepted those Amendments and that is clearly referred to in the Determination that was read out this morning. On behalf of the Government, I stated yesterday that the Government is accepting, in its entirety, the Amendments which have been suggested by the Supreme Court. So, during the Committee Stage on Thursday afternoon, the Government will move those Amendments, they will be included in the Bill and with those Amendments, the Bill can be passed in this Parliament with a simple majority. That is the effect of the Determination of the Supreme Court. There is no doubt whatsoever that there is no need for a two-thirds majority, there is no need for a Referendum and the Bill can be passed with a simple majority.
I thank you for your indulgence, Hon. Presiding Member.
[.. (.18] ( ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Ajith Nivard Cabraal - State Minister of Money and Capital Market and State Enterprise Reforms) , .

Parliament adjourned accordingly until 10.00 a.m. on Wednesday, 19th May, 2021.
